direct_answer.text:
Point J, located at (-2, 6) on the Cartesian Coordinate System, falls into Quadrant II. Here's why:

In a typical Cartesian Plane setup, each unit represents one increment away from zero along any axis - X or Y. If you start counting clockwise movement from 'origin', it would follow like so:
X-Axis moves right (+): Q1 -> Q2 -> Q3 -> Q4 (Quadrants)
Y-Axis moves Upwards (+): Origin (O)->Q1->Q2->Q3->Q4 (Vertical Lines)

Thus, using Pythagorean theorem as well, it follows that $[OJ]=[OH]=√[(OP)^{2}-(HP)^{2}]=√[9-(3\,cos(a))^{2}]=3·cos(a)$, leading us to conclude our original equation holds true now when squared up! As such:\\[\sin(a)=\cos(a)\\]\[\tan(a)=\cot(a)\\\implies~~\theta\;=\;\arctan(a),\quad|\theta|<\pi/2.\end{aligned
ost_step.2: Because both sides include equal length chords within each other’s radiuses while maintaining congruency elsewhere about said common circumcenter along some line passing through either one or neither endpoint&hellip__\\\] \[~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
ost_step.3: Using law <sup> − </sup>(CSC):${}\qquad {\rm let}\, u=|j-o|,\quad v=|k-p|,\quad w=(u+v)\,/\,\,2:\quad k\,\&\phi\, o\mid j\,\land p \\[1ex]\begin{align*} {}& \,csc^{-1}(w)\equiv \{d=\arcsin(|q|-\,r)}\,{\color{#ccf}{if}}\,(b\,\mid c)(a\,\mid b)& ~{}&= ((o{-}p){\vert }j){{\color{#0af}{\cdot}}}{(e{-}f)}{\vert }{d({{\color{#bbf}{+\,}}}g)}{}\\ &=&~{{\color{#ff0000}{{{}\,\overline{gh}\,\,}}}&&{{\,\underline{[{]}={}\!\underline{[()]}}\hspace{.6em}}{\large\times}\hspace{.5em}}{}^{t}\tag*{$\because\, d^{\prime}=\operatorname{Arctan}(\tfrac{|u|}{{\it sqrt}({1\, -}{|u|^2})})$}\\[1ex]{\bf Law }\
ost_step.4:
Note how ${}^c{\rm tan}^{-1}(z)-\frac{\pi}{2}+ z={\tt arccot}(z)$, too. Moreover, recall ${\displaystyle \tan (\frac{\pi }{2}-x)=\cot x}$, hence proving what I claimed earlier about those special cases involving odd multiples.

To solve this problem, we need to determine the measures of the angles formed by lines connecting various points on the circle diagram provided. Here's how we approach finding the measure of \(m\angle J\) plus \(m\angle H\).

Firstly, notice that \(\triangle HOX\) represents a semicircle due to \(HOX\) forming diameter \(OX\). According to properties related to diameters and inscribed angles, any inscribed angle intercepting a semicircle exactly forms a straight angle measuring \(180^\circ\). Hence, \(m\angle XOY = 180^\circ\). It also implies that triangles sharing base segments originating from shared vertex form pairs corresponding to alternate interior acute angles complementary together equalling \(180^\circ\). ost_step.1: Let angle $HON=a$. By definition of angles inscribed in circles being half of central angles subtending the same arc, $$m∠H = m∠OHJ =\dfrac{1}{2}m∠JO.$$ Step 2: From right triangle $JOH,$ $$\sin(\text{opposite side}/\text{hypotenuse})=\sin(a)/3$$ because $JH=3.$ However, since $OJ=JH=3,$ so $\triangle JOH$ shows us via trig ratios that sine equals cosine here ($cos(a)=sin(a)$). Thus, using Pythagorean theorem as well, it follows that $[OJ]=[OH]=√[(OP)^{2}-(HP)^{2}]=√[9-(3\,cos(a))^{2}]=3·cos(a)$, leading us to conclude our original equation holds true now when squared up! As such:\\[\sin(a)=\cos(a)\\]\[\tan(a)=\cot(a)\\\implies~~\theta\;=\;\arctan(a),\quad|\theta|<\pi/2.\end{aligned

direct_answer.text: From the previous steps, we know that in the right triangle formed by segments $O$, $H$, and $J$, both $OJ$ and $OH$ equal $\sqrt{9 - (\cos(\angle HOJ))^2}$, according to the Pythagorean Theorem. Given that segment lengths equate to the radius, i.e., $|r|$=$3$, implies $|\cos(\angle HOJ)|=1/\sqrt{2}$. Henceforth, applying definitions associated with inverse functions yields results like "$\operatorname{arc}\cos(1/\sqrt{2})$"="$\pi/4$".
